name: places/ChIJaR-viRtZwokRf_faBQBjNHE
formattedAddress: 7th floor, 151 W 34th St., New York, NY 10001, USA
adrFormatAddress: 7th floor, 151 W 34th St., New York, NY 10001, USA

editorialSummary.text: Chain retailer providing an assortment of brand-name children's toys, games, electronics & gear.

originalText.text: This is my favorite toy store in the most iconic of locations. I've taken so many kids here (and the old Times Square location) and together we spend so many hours without out even realizing it! The dinosaur is awesome and so is the Ferris Wheel. One could buy most of these toys in a big box retailer like a Walmart but it's nothing like visiting a Toys "Я" Us

originalText.text: Really awesome store with a lot of great nostalgic toys r us items as well as many new modern items as well. I highly recommend shopping here.

text.text: Really awesome store with a lot of great nostalgic toys r us items as well as many new modern items as well. I highly recommend shopping here.

originalText.text: Toys R Us is back and pretty cool! I don't think it's nearly what it used to be, but this is still a cool place to visit. Don't expect a ton to do here as it is just a part of Macy's. There are a few things kids can do such as a giant Lite Brite, photo opportunity with the giraffe and another spot, and a few toys to choose from. Giant Lite Brite to me was the coolest thing. It's about 4ft-6ft and lots of different colors. I was able to write hello, draw a PokeBall, and make a little kirby. This place is a little difficult to find if you use the escalators, so I recommend using the elevators.

text.text: Toys R Us is back and pretty cool! I don't think it's nearly what it used to be, but this is still a cool place to visit. Don't expect a ton to do here as it is just a part of Macy's. There are a few things kids can do such as a giant Lite Brite, photo opportunity with the giraffe and another spot, and a few toys to choose from. Giant Lite Brite to me was the coolest thing. It's about 4ft-6ft and lots of different colors. I was able to write hello, draw a PokeBall, and make a little kirby. This place is a little difficult to find if you use the escalators, so I recommend using the elevators.

originalText.text:
It will not live up to the nostalgia, I'm sorry to say. This Toys R Us is about the size of a Foot Locker, taking up maybe 1/8 of the 7th floor of Macy's. It's got areas focused on age and brand of toy, like Legos, Hot Wheels, Barbie - but it doesn't compete with the range of different toys that a true Toys R Us would have. The prices also aren't clear, a lot of items don't have prices, and the ones that do are confused by sale signs on the shelves. It was also widely crowded, with kids climbing on top of installations in a mini-playground, smearing play dough all over the place. The line to buy anything looked daunting enough to discourage anyone but the most committed.

All in all, it's a toy store inside Macy's. It something fun for the kids to do for 30 minutes in an otherwise busy midtown area.

originalText.text:
Opening day it was pretty empty of customers abd the shelves were stocked and organized:  barbie, Lego. Pokémon. Toys R US exclusives.... but!  I imagine it will be bonkers soon.  The aisles are not particularly wide.  The selections are not particularly extensive.  BuT!  Toys!  And!  Bonus 'activities"  - take your picture next yo impressive Lego creations if Macy's and or the Tatum if liberty;  big white Furry Llama and unicorn and [my favorite]  SLOTH!
Anyway-  hohoho.   Toy buying time is nigh.
